repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Irrigation Subsector Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, though institutional
            development impacts were only modest. Lessons are as
            follows. While the project focus was to provide technical
            assistance (TA) for the irrigation sub-sector, the project
            did nonetheless help in restructuring, organizing, and
            strengthening institutions, in formulating policy, and
            proposing, and drafting laws for the overall water sector.
            Such program objectives are difficult to implement within a
            TA project at the sub-sectoral level, but the requirement of
            a sectoral project initiative does lead to successful
            sectoral reform implementation. Moreover, the provision of
            TA as part of the transfer (privatization) process - of
            public irrigation systems to user groups (WUAs), as in this
            case - was the critical ingredient, and catalyst for
            motivating farmers, a success attributed among others, to
            the TA in agricultural, and engineering aspects of better
            farm management, combined with rehabilitation works,
            interventions that significantly raised the value added of
            small farm production units. However, given that existing
            WUAs had been created specifically for the purpose of tariff
            collection, most members did not consider them as legitimate
            community organizations, and participation was thus low and
            weak. But the key element in making the transfer process
            effective was the adoption of WUAs democratic management
            practices, enhancing an active participation which
            contributed to the project's success. It is suggested
            that reorganization of existing institutions should have an
            education component, as well as incentive mechanisms.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Irrigation Subsector Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The central thrust of the Irrigation
            Subsector Technical Assistance Project is to assist the
            Government in undertaking the process of modernization of
            the irrigation subsector, the major user of water resources
            in the country. The required institutional reform will be
            addressed sequentially, first by streamlining the normative
            and regulatory role of the public sector in the development
            of the irrigation subsector. This will be accompanied by
            actions to initiate a process of decentralization and
            privatization, in which existing regional institutions will
            be strengthened to effectively assume the lead role in
            assisting user organizations to take over the management of
            existing public irrigation systems. Once these subsectors
            reforms are underway, the project will promote the
            incorporation of other subsectors (urban water supply,
            hydro-electricity) in order to establish a sustainable and
            integrated approach to water resource policies and
            management in the country. From a legal standpoint, the
            current Water Law does not restrict the implementation of
            the proposed restructuring of institutions involved in
            irrigation. If required, the reform process will thus be
            carried out initially through administrative mechanisms, to
            be later formalized within the revised new Water Law. Such
            legislation will also complement the broader policy reforms
            currently being adopted by the Ministry of Agriculture. A
            second key element of the project will be the development of
            a comprehensive set of technical, economic and environmental
            criteria to be applied in the prioritization and selection
            of future public investments in irrigation. These criteria
            will form the basis for the analysis of all existing
            irrigation works to determine those that objectively merit
            investments for completion and/or rehabilitation. As a
            result, an important output of the technical assistance to
            be provided under the proposed project will be the full
            preparation of a medium-term Investment Plan, to be
            implemented within the legal and operational framework
            developed during the project.
